Assistant: Sure, I'd be happy to explain Getting Started with Radix Themes in radix-ui-themes.

# Getting Started with Radix Themes

Install Radix Themes and start building in minutes. Radix Themes is a pre-styled component library that is designed to work out of the box with minimal configuration.Here's a quick rundown of what this is about:

## Overview

Radix Themes is a pre-styled component library that is designed to work out of the box with minimal configuration. If you are looking for the unstyled components, go to Radix Primitives.

## Installation

Getting up and running is quick and easy.

## 1. Install Radix Themes

Install the package from your command line.

## 2. Import the CSS file

Import the global CSS file at the root of your application.

## 3. Add the Theme component

Add `Theme` to your application, wrapping the root component inside of `body`.

## 4. Start building

You are now ready to use Radix Themes components.

## Customizing your theme

Configuration is managed and applied via the Theme component.

## Basic configuration

Pass configuration to the Theme to customize appearance.

## Using the theme panel

ThemePanel is a drop-in component that allows you to preview the theme in real time.

## Take it further

Get the most out of Radix Themes by exploring more concepts and features.

This should give you a solid starting point!

# Code Component Documentation

This documentation provides an overview of the Code component, its API reference, examples, and usage guidelines.Here's a quick rundown of what this is about:

## Overview

The Code component marks text to signify a short fragment of computer code.

## API Reference

This component is based on the `code` element and supports common margin props.

## Examples

Various examples demonstrating the usage of the Code component with different props.

This should give you a solid starting point!

Utilize the `variant` prop to change the visual style of the code component.

Assign specific colors using the `color` prop for better visual distinction.

Increase color contrast with the `highContrast` prop for better accessibility.

Set the text weight using the `weight` prop to emphasize certain code snippets.

Use the `truncate` prop to handle overflow text gracefully.

Stick to these, and you'll avoid a lot of headaches!

Assistant: Sure, I'd be happy to explain Radix UI Themes Documentation in radix-ui-themes.

# Radix UI Themes Documentation

Comprehensive documentation for Radix UI themes, including components, layout, typography, and utilities.Here's a quick rundown of what this is about:

## Overview

This section provides links to getting started, styling, layout, releases, and resources.

## Theme

This section covers theme-related topics such as overview, color, dark mode, typography, spacing, breakpoints, radius, shadows, and cursors.

## Layout

This section includes layout components like Box, Flex, Grid, Container, and Section.

## Typography

This section covers typography components such as Text, Heading, Blockquote, Code, Em, Kbd, Link, Quote, and Strong.

## Components

This section lists various components available in Radix UI, including Alert Dialog, Aspect Ratio, Avatar, Badge, Button, Callout, Card, Checkbox, Checkbox Group, Checkbox Cards, Context Menu, Data List, Dialog, Dropdown Menu, Hover Card, Icon Button, Inset, Popover, Progress, Radio, Radio Group, Radio Cards, Scroll Area, Segmented Control, Select, Separator, Skeleton, Slider, Spinner, Switch, Table, Tabs, Tab Nav, Text Area, Text Field, and Tooltip.

## Utilities

This section includes utility components such as Accessible Icon, Portal, Reset, Slot, Theme, and Visually Hidden.

## Link

Semantic element for navigation between pages. This section includes API reference, examples, and various props for the Link component.

This should give you a solid starting point!

User: Can you give me some code examples for Radix UI Themes Documentation in radix-ui-themes?

Assistant: Absolutely! Here are some practical examples to help you out:

**Basic Link Example**:

```yaml
<Link href="#">Sign up</Link>
```

This snippet shows you how to basic link example, which is an important aspect of radix ui themes documentation.

**Size Prop Example**:

```yaml
<Flex direction="column" gap="3">
	<Link href="#" size="1">Sign up</Link>
	<Link href="#" size="2">Sign up</Link>
	<Link href="#" size="3">Sign up</Link>
	<Link href="#" size="4">Sign up</Link>
	<Link href="#" size="5">Sign up</Link>
	<Link href="#" size="6">Sign up</Link>
	<Link href="#" size="7">Sign up</Link>
	<Link href="#" size="8">Sign up</Link>
	<Link href="#" size="9">Sign up</Link>
</Flex>
```

This snippet shows you how to size prop example, which is an important aspect of radix ui themes documentation.

**Weight Prop Example**:

```yaml
<Flex direction="column">
	<Link href="#" weight="regular">Sign up</Link>
	<Link href="#" weight="medium">Sign up</Link>
	<Link href="#" weight="bold">Sign up</Link>
</Flex>
```

This snippet shows you how to weight prop example, which is an important aspect of radix ui themes documentation.

**Truncate Prop Example**:

```yaml
<Flex maxWidth="150px">
	<Link href="#" truncate>Sign up to the newsletter</Link>
</Flex>
```

This snippet shows you how to truncate prop example, which is an important aspect of radix ui themes documentation.

**Color Prop Example**:

```yaml
<Flex direction="column">
	<Link href="#" color="indigo">Sign up</Link>
	<Link href="#" color="cyan">Sign up</Link>
	<Link href="#" color="orange">Sign up</Link>
	<Link href="#" color="crimson">Sign up</Link>
</Flex>
```

This snippet shows you how to color prop example, which is an important aspect of radix ui themes documentation.

**High-contrast Prop Example**:

```yaml
<Flex direction="column">
	<Link href="#" color="gray">Sign up</Link>
	<Link href="#" color="gray" highContrast>Sign up</Link>
</Flex>
```

This snippet shows you how to high-contrast prop example, which is an important aspect of radix ui themes documentation.

**Underline Prop Example**:

```yaml
<Flex direction="column">
	<Link href="#" underline="hover">Sign up</Link>
	<Link href="#" underline="always">Sign up</Link>
</Flex>
```

This snippet shows you how to underline prop example, which is an important aspect of radix ui themes documentation.

Assistant: Sure, I'd be happy to explain Tabs in radix-ui-themes.

# Tabs

Set of content sections to be displayed one at a time.Here's a quick rundown of what this is about:

## Overview

This section provides an overview of the Tabs component, including links to getting started, styling, layout, releases, and resources.

## API Reference

This component inherits props from the Tabs primitive and supports common margin props.

## Root

Contains all component parts.

## List

Contains the triggers that sit alongside the active content.

## Trigger

The button that activates its associated content.

## Content

Contains the content associated with each trigger.

## Examples

This section provides examples of how to use the Tabs component, including size, color, and high-contrast options.

## Navigation

Tabs should not be used for page navigation. Use Tab Nav instead, which is designed for this purpose.

This should give you a solid starting point!

**Basic Tabs Example**:

```yaml
<Tabs.Root defaultValue="account">

	<Tabs.List>

		<Tabs.Trigger value="account">Account</Tabs.Trigger>

		<Tabs.Trigger value="documents">Documents</Tabs.Trigger>

		<Tabs.Trigger value="settings">Settings</Tabs.Trigger>

	</Tabs.List>

	<Box pt="3">

		<Tabs.Content value="account">

			<Text size="2">Make changes to your account.</Text>

		</Tabs.Content>

		<Tabs.Content value="documents">

			<Text size="2">Access and update your documents.</Text>

		</Tabs.Content>

		<Tabs.Content value="settings">

			<Text size="2">Edit your profile or update contact information.</Text>

		</Tabs.Content>

	</Box>

</Tabs.Root>
```

# Radix UI Themes Documentation

Comprehensive guide to Radix UI themes, including components, layout, typography, and spacing.Here's a quick rundown of what this is about:

## Overview

This section provides links to various topics including Getting Started, Styling, Layout, Releases, and Resources.

## Theme

This section covers theme-related topics such as Overview, Color, Dark mode, Typography, Spacing, Breakpoints, Radius, Shadows, and Cursors.

## Layout

This section includes components related to layout such as Box, Flex, Grid, Container, and Section.

## Typography

This section covers typography components including Text, Heading, Blockquote, Code, Em, Kbd, Link, Quote, and Strong.

## Components

This section lists various components available in Radix UI such as Alert Dialog, Aspect Ratio, Avatar, Badge, Button, Callout, Card, Checkbox, Checkbox Group, Checkbox Cards, Context Menu, Data List, Dialog, Dropdown Menu, Hover Card, Icon Button, Inset, Popover, Progress, Radio, Radio Group, Radio Cards, Scroll Area, Segmented Control, Select, Separator, Skeleton, Slider, Spinner, Switch, Table, Tabs, Tab Nav, Text Area, Text Field, and Tooltip.

## Utilities

This section includes utility components such as Accessible Icon, Portal, Reset, Slot, Theme, and Visually Hidden.

## Guides

This section provides guides on various topics.

## Spacing

Overview of the space scale and scaling options.

## Space scale

Spacing values are derived from a 9-step scale, which is used for props such as margin and padding. These props accept numeric strings from '1' to '9', which correspond to the steps in the scale.

## Scaling

Values which affect layout (spacing, font size, line height) scale relatively to each other based on the scaling value defined in your Theme.

This should give you a solid starting point!

# Radix UI Themes Documentation

Comprehensive documentation for Radix UI themes, including components, layout, typography, and utilities.Here's a quick rundown of what this is about:

## Overview

This section provides links to getting started, styling, layout, releases, and resources.

## Theme

This section covers theme-related topics such as overview, color, dark mode, typography, spacing, breakpoints, radius, shadows, and cursors.

## Layout

This section includes layout components like Box, Flex, Grid, Container, and Section.

## Typography

This section discusses typography components including Text, Heading, Blockquote, Code, Em, Kbd, Link, Quote, and Strong.

## Components

This section lists various components such as Alert Dialog, Aspect Ratio, Avatar, Badge, Button, Callout, Card, Checkbox, Checkbox Group, Checkbox Cards, Context Menu, Data List, Dialog, Dropdown Menu, Hover Card, Icon Button, Inset, Popover, Progress, Radio, Radio Group, Radio Cards, Scroll Area, Segmented Control, Select, Separator, Skeleton, Slider, Spinner, Switch, Table, Tabs, Tab Nav, Text Area, Text Field, and Tooltip.

## Utilities

This section includes utility components like Accessible Icon, Portal, Reset, Slot, Theme, and Visually Hidden.

## Components - Inset

Applies a negative margin to allow content to bleed into the surrounding container. Includes links to view source, report an issue, and view in playground.

This should give you a solid starting point!

User: Can you explain what Skeleton Component Documentation is in radix-ui-themes?

Assistant: Sure, I'd be happy to explain Skeleton Component Documentation in radix-ui-themes.

# Skeleton Component Documentation

Documentation for the Skeleton component in Radix UI, including usage, API reference, and examples.Here's a quick rundown of what this is about:

## Overview

Replaces content with same shape placeholder that indicates a loading state.

## API Reference

This component is based on the `span` element and supports [common margin props](https://www.radix-ui.com/themes/docs/overview/layout#margin-props).

| Prop | Type | Default |
| --- | --- | --- |
| `loading` | `boolean` | `true` |
| `width` | `Responsive<string>` | No default value |
| `minWidth` | `Responsive<string>` | No default value |
| `maxWidth` | `Responsive<string>` | No default value |
| `height` | `Responsive<string>` | No default value |
| `minHeight` | `Responsive<string>` | No default value |
| `maxHeight` | `Responsive<string>` | No default value |

## Examples

### Size
Use the width and height props to manually control the size of the skeleton.

```jsx
<Skeleton width="48px" height="48px" />
```

### With children
Use the `loading` prop to control whether the skeleton or its children are displayed. Skeleton preserves the dimensions of children when they are hidden and disables interactive elements.

```jsx
<Flex gap="4">
	<Skeleton loading={true}>
		<Switch defaultChecked />
	</Skeleton>
	<Skeleton loading={false}>
		<Switch defaultChecked />
	</Skeleton>
</Flex>
```

### With text
When using Skeleton with text, you’d usually wrap the text node itself rather than the parent element. This ensures that the text is replaced with a placeholder of the same size:

```jsx
<Container size="1">
	<Flex direction="column" gap="2">
		<Text>
			<Skeleton>Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet.</Skeleton>
		</Text>
		<Skeleton>
			<Text>Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet</Text>
		</Skeleton>
	</Flex>
</Container>
```

The difference is especially noticeable when wrapping longer paragraphs:

```jsx
<Container size="1">
	<Flex direction="column" gap="3">
		<Text>
			<Skeleton>
				Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Pellentesque
				felis tellus, efficitur id convallis a, viverra eget libero. Nam magna
				erat, fringilla sed commodo sed, aliquet nec magna.
			</Skeleton>
		</Text>
		<Skeleton>
			<Text>
				Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Pellentesque
				felis tellus, efficitur id convallis a, viverra eget libero. Nam magna
				erat, fringilla sed commodo sed, aliquet nec magna.
			</Text>
		</Skeleton>
	</Flex>
</Container>
```

This should give you a solid starting point!

```yaml

		</Button>

	<Popover.Content width="360px">

		<Flex gap="3">

			<Avatar
				size="2"

				radius="full"
			/>

			<Box flexGrow="1">

				<TextArea placeholder="Write a comment…" style={{ height: 80 }} />

				<Flex gap="3" mt="3" justify="between">

					<Flex align="center" gap="2" asChild>

						<Text as="label" size="2">

							<Checkbox />

							<Text>Send to group</Text>

						</Text>

					</Flex>

					<Popover.Close>

						<Button size="1">Comment</Button>

					</Popover.Close>

				</Flex>

			</Box>

		</Flex>

	</Popover.Content>

</Popover.Root>
```

text:
System: You are a helpful radix-ui-themes expert.

User: Can you explain what Styling with Radix Themes is in radix-ui-themes?

Assistant: Sure, I'd be happy to explain Styling with Radix Themes in radix-ui-themes.

# Styling with Radix Themes

How to approach styling with Radix Themes.Here's a quick rundown of what this is about:

## Overview

Radix Themes does not come with a built-in styling system. There’s no `css` or `sx` prop, and it does not use any styling libraries internally. Under the hood, it’s built with vanilla CSS.

## What you get

The components in Radix Themes are relatively closed—they come with a set of styles that aren’t always easily overridden. They are customizable within what’s allowed by their props and the theme configuration. However, you also get access to the same CSS variables that power the Radix Themes components. You can use these tokens to create custom components that naturally feel at home in the original theme. Changes to the token system are treated as breaking.

## Overriding styles

Beyond simple style overrides, we recommend using the components as-is, or create your own versions using the same building blocks. Most components do have `className` and `style` props, but if you find yourself needing to override a lot of styles, it’s a good sign that you should either:
- Try to achieve what you need with the existing props and theme configuration.
- See whether you can achieve your design by tweaking the underlying token system.
- Create your own component using lower-level building blocks, such [Primitives](https://www.radix-ui.com/primitives) and [Colors](https://www.radix-ui.com/colors).
- Reconsider whether Radix Themes is the right fit for your project.

## Tailwind

Tailwind is _great_. Yet, if you plan to use Radix Themes with Tailwind, keep in mind how its ergonomics may encourage you to create complex styles on the fly, sometimes reaching into the component internals without friction.

## Custom components

If you need to create a custom component, use the same building blocks that Radix Themes uses:
- [Theme](https://www.radix-ui.com/themes/docs/theme/overview) tokens that power the components
- [Radix Primitives](https://www.radix-ui.com/primitives), a library of accessible, unstyled components
- [Radix Colors](https://www.radix-ui.com/colors), a color system for building beautiful websites and apps.

## Common issues

### z-index conflicts
Out of the box, portalled Radix Themes components can be nested and stacked in any order without conflicts. For example, you can open a popover that opens a dialog, which in turn opens another popover. They all stack on top of each other in the order they were opened:

Recursive popover

When building your own components, use the following rules to avoid z-index conflicts:
- Don’t use `z-index` values other than `auto`, `0`, or `-1` in rare cases.
- Render the elements that should stack on top of each other in portals.

## Next.js import order

As of Next.js 13.0 to 14.1, the import order of CSS files in `app/**/layout.tsx` is not guaranteed, so Radix Themes may overwrite your own styles even when written correctly:
```js
import "@radix-ui/themes/styles.css";
import "./my-styles.css";
```
This Next.js issue may come and go sporadically, or happen only in development or production.

## Tailwind base styles

As of Tailwind v3, styles produced by the `@tailwind` directive are usually appended after any imported CSS, no matter the original import order. In particular, Tailwind’s [button reset](https://github.com/tailwindlabs/tailwindcss/blob/7361468f77500105b0559e879e121f34306e8da2/src/css/preflight.css#L197-L204) style may interfere with Radix Themes buttons, rendering certain buttons without a background color.

## Missing styles in portals

When you render a custom portal in a Radix Themes project, it will naturally appear outside of the root `<Theme>` component, which means it won’t have access to most of the theme tokens and styles. To fix that, wrap the portal content with another `<Theme>`:
```jsx
// Implementation example of a custom dialog using the low-level Dialog primitive
import { Dialog } from "radix-ui";
import { Theme } from "@radix-ui/themes";
function MyCustomDialog() {
	return (
		<Dialog.Root>
			<Dialog.Trigger>Open</Dialog.Trigger>
			<Dialog.Portal>
				<Theme>
					<Dialog.Overlay />
					<Dialog.Content>
						<Dialog.Title />
						<Dialog.Description />
						<Dialog.Close />
					</Dialog.Content>
				</Theme>
			</Dialog.Portal>
		</Dialog.Root>
	);
}
```},{

This should give you a solid starting point!

text:
System: You are a helpful radix-ui-themes expert.

User: Can you explain what Radix UI Themes Documentation is in radix-ui-themes?

Assistant: Sure, I'd be happy to explain Radix UI Themes Documentation in radix-ui-themes.

# Radix UI Themes Documentation

Comprehensive documentation for Radix UI themes, including components, utilities, and examples.Here's a quick rundown of what this is about:

## Overview

This section provides an overview of the Radix UI themes, including links to getting started, styling, layout, releases, and resources.

## Theme

Details about theme customization, including color, dark mode, typography, spacing, breakpoints, radius, and shadows.

## Layout

Information on layout components such as Box, Flex, Grid, Container, and Section.

## Typography

Details on typography components including Text, Heading, Blockquote, Code, Em, Kbd, Link, Quote, and Strong.

## Components

A list of various components available in Radix UI themes, including Alert Dialog, Avatar, Button, Card, Checkbox, Dialog, Dropdown Menu, and more.

## Utilities

Utilities provided by Radix UI themes, including Accessible Icon, Portal, Reset, Slot, Theme, and Visually Hidden.

## Reset

The Reset component is used to aggressively reset browser styles on a specific element. It renders a Slot primitive that accepts a single React element as its child, removes opinionated browser styles, sets idiomatic layout defaults, and adds box-sizing: border-box.

## API Reference

Detailed API reference for the Reset component, including its properties and usage.

## Examples

Examples of using the Reset component with various HTML elements such as Anchor, Abbreviation, Address, Article, Aside, Bold, Button, and more.

This should give you a solid starting point!

# Radix UI Themes Documentation

Comprehensive documentation for Radix UI themes, including components, layout, typography, and utilities.Here's a quick rundown of what this is about:

## Overview

This section provides links to getting started, styling, layout, releases, and resources.

## Theme

This section covers theme-related topics such as overview, color, dark mode, typography, spacing, breakpoints, radius, shadows, and cursors.

## Layout

This section includes components related to layout such as Box, Flex, Grid, Container, and Section.

## Typography

This section covers typography components including Text, Heading, Blockquote, Code, Em, Kbd, Link, Quote, and Strong.

## Components

This section lists various components available in Radix UI such as Alert Dialog, Avatar, Button, Card, Checkbox, Dialog, Dropdown Menu, and more.

## Utilities

This section includes utility components like Accessible Icon, Portal, Reset, Slot, Theme, and Visually Hidden.

## Section

Denotes a section of page content.

This should give you a solid starting point!

# Radix UI Themes Documentation

Comprehensive documentation for Radix UI themes, including components, layout, typography, and utilities.Here's a quick rundown of what this is about:

## Overview

This section provides links to getting started, styling, layout, releases, and resources.

## Theme

This section covers theme-related topics such as overview, color, dark mode, typography, spacing, breakpoints, radius, shadows, and cursors.

## Layout

This section includes components for layout such as Box, Flex, Grid, Container, and Section.

## Typography

This section covers typography components including Text, Heading, Blockquote, Code, Em, Kbd, Link, Quote, and Strong.

## Components

This section lists various components available in Radix UI such as Alert Dialog, Aspect Ratio, Avatar, Badge, Button, Callout, Card, Checkbox, and many more.

## Utilities

This section includes utility components like Accessible Icon, Portal, Reset, Slot, Theme, and Visually Hidden.

## Flex

Component for creating flex layouts. This section includes a code example and a link to the API reference.

This should give you a solid starting point!

User: Can you give me some code examples for Slider Component Documentation in radix-ui-themes?

Assistant: Absolutely! Here are some practical examples to help you out:

**Basic Slider Example**:

```yaml
<Slider defaultValue={[50]} />
```

This snippet shows you how to basic slider example, which is an important aspect of slider component documentation.

**Size Example**:

```yaml
<Flex direction="column" gap="4" maxWidth="300px">
	<Slider defaultValue={[25]} size="1" />
	<Slider defaultValue={[50]} size="2" />
	<Slider defaultValue={[75]} size="3" />
</Flex>
```

This snippet shows you how to size example, which is an important aspect of slider component documentation.

**Variant Example**:

```yaml
<Flex direction="column" gap="4" maxWidth="300px">
	<Slider defaultValue={[25]} variant="surface" />
	<Slider defaultValue={[50]} variant="classic" />
	<Slider defaultValue={[75]} variant="soft" />
</Flex>
```

This snippet shows you how to variant example, which is an important aspect of slider component documentation.

**Color Example**:

```yaml
<Flex direction="column" gap="4" maxWidth="300px">
	<Slider defaultValue={[20]} color="indigo" />
	<Slider defaultValue={[40]} color="cyan" />
	<Slider defaultValue={[60]} color="orange" />
	<Slider defaultValue={[80]} color="crimson" />
</Flex>
```

This snippet shows you how to color example, which is an important aspect of slider component documentation.

**High-contrast Example**:

```yaml
<Grid columns="2" gap="4">
	<Slider defaultValue={[10]} color="indigo" />
	<Slider defaultValue={[10]} color="indigo" highContrast />
	<Slider defaultValue={[30]} color="cyan" />
	<Slider defaultValue={[30]} color="cyan" highContrast />
	<Slider defaultValue={[50]} color="orange" />
	<Slider defaultValue={[50]} color="orange" highContrast />
	<Slider defaultValue={[70]} color="crimson" />
	<Slider defaultValue={[70]} color="crimson" highContrast />
	<Slider defaultValue={[90]} color="gray" />
	<Slider defaultValue={[90]} color="gray" highContrast />
</Grid>
```

This snippet shows you how to high-contrast example, which is an important aspect of slider component documentation.

**Radius Example**:

```yaml
<Flex direction="column" gap="4" maxWidth="300px">
	<Slider defaultValue={[25]} radius="none" />
	<Slider defaultValue={[50]} radius="small" />
	<Slider defaultValue={[75]} radius="full" />
</Flex>
```

This snippet shows you how to radius example, which is an important aspect of slider component documentation.

**Range Slider Example**:

```yaml
<Slider defaultValue={[25, 75]} />
```

This snippet shows you how to range slider example, which is an important aspect of slider component documentation.

# Radix UI Themes Documentation

Comprehensive guide to using Radix UI themes, including components, layout, typography, and customization options.Here's a quick rundown of what this is about:

## Overview

This section provides links to getting started, styling, layout, releases, and resources.

## Theme

Details about the theme component, including color, dark mode, typography, spacing, breakpoints, radius, shadows, and cursors.

## Layout

Information on layout components such as Box, Flex, Grid, Container, and Section.

## Typography

Covers typography components including Text, Heading, Blockquote, Code, Em, Kbd, Link, Quote, and Strong.

## Components

A list of various components available in Radix UI, including Alert Dialog, Avatar, Button, Card, Checkbox, Dialog, Dropdown Menu, and more.

## Utilities

Utilities provided by Radix UI, including Accessible Icon, Portal, Reset, Slot, Theme, and Visually Hidden.

## Guides

Guides on using the Theme component, including anatomy, variants, examples, and tokens.

This should give you a solid starting point!

# Separator

Visually or semantically separates content.Here's a quick rundown of what this is about:

## Overview

Tools for building high-quality, accessible UI.

## API Reference

This component inherits props from the Separator primitive and supports common margin props.

## Examples

### Size
Use the size prop to control the size of the separator. The largest step takes full width or height of the container.

### Color
Use the color prop to assign a specific color.

### Orientation
Use the orientation prop to control whether the separator is horizontal or vertical.

This should give you a solid starting point!

# Theme Documentation

Documentation for the Theme component in Radix UI, detailing its API, examples, and usage.Here's a quick rundown of what this is about:

## Overview

Wraps all or part of a React tree to provide theme configuration.

## API Reference

For an overview of theming see the overview page.

## Examples

Various examples demonstrating the usage of the Theme component.

## Nesting

Nest another theme to modify configuration for a specific subtree. Configuration is inherited from the parent.

## Component overrides

Override configuration per component by passing any supported prop directly to that component.

This should give you a solid starting point!

System: You are a helpful radix-ui-themes expert.

User: Can you give me some code examples for Theme Documentation in radix-ui-themes?

Assistant: Absolutely! Here are some practical examples to help you out:

**Basic configuration**:

```yaml
<Box maxWidth="400px">
	<Card size="2">
		<Flex direction="column" gap="3">
			<Grid gap="1">
				<Text as="div" weight="bold" size="2" mb="1">
					Feedback
				</Text>
				<TextArea placeholder="Write your feedback…" />
			</Grid>
			<Flex asChild justify="between">
				<label>
					<Text color="gray" size="2">
						Attach screenshot?
					</Text>
					<Switch size="1" defaultChecked />
				</label>
			</Flex>
			<Grid columns="2" gap="2">
				<Button variant="surface">Back</Button>
				<Button>Send</Button>
			</Grid>
			</Flex>
	</Card>
</Box>
```

This snippet shows you how to basic configuration, which is an important aspect of theme documentation.

**Nesting**:

```yaml
<Card size="2">
	<Flex gap="6">
		<Flex direction="column" gap="3">
			<Heading as="h5" size="2">
				Global
			</Heading>
			<Grid gap="1">
				<Text as="div" weight="bold" size="2" mb="1">
					Feedback
				</Text>
				<TextArea placeholder="Write your feedback…" />
			</Grid>
			<Button>Send</Button>
		</Flex>
		<Theme accentColor="cyan" radius="full">
			<Card size="2">
				<Flex gap="6">
					<Flex direction="column" gap="3">
						<Heading as="h5" size="2">
							Child
						</Heading>
						<Grid gap="1">
							<Text as="div" weight="bold" size="2" mb="1">
								Feedback
							</Text>
							<TextArea placeholder="Write your feedback…" />
						</Grid>
						<Button>Send</Button>
					</Flex>
					<Theme accentColor="orange">
						<Card size="2">
							<Flex direction="column" gap="3">
								<Heading as="h5" size="2">
								Grandchild
							</Heading>
								<Grid gap="1">
									<Text as="div" weight="bold" size="2" mb="1">
										Feedback
									</Text>
									<TextArea placeholder="Write your feedback…" />
								</Grid>
								<Button>Send</Button>
							</Flex>
						</Card>
					</Theme>
				</Flex>
			</Card>
		</Theme>
	</Flex>
</Card>
```

This snippet shows you how to nesting, which is an important aspect of theme documentation.

**Component overrides**:

```yaml
<Box maxWidth="400px">
	<Card size="2">
		<Flex direction="column" gap="3">
			<Grid gap="1">
				<Text as="div" weight="bold" size="2" mb="1">
					Feedback
				</Text>
				<TextArea placeholder="Write your feedback…" />
			</Grid>
			<Flex asChild justify="between">
				<label>
					<Text color="gray" size="2">
						Attach screenshot?
					</Text>
					<Switch
						size="1"
						color="orange"
						radius="full"
						defaultChecked
					/>
				</label>
			</Flex>
			<Grid columns="2" gap="2">
				<Button variant="surface">Back</Button>
				<Button color="cyan" radius="full">
					Send
				</Button>
			</Grid>
			</Flex>
	</Card>
</Box>
```

This snippet shows you how to component overrides, which is an important aspect of theme documentation.

# Checkbox Component Documentation

Documentation for the Checkbox component in Radix UI, including usage, API reference, examples, and best practices.Here's a quick rundown of what this is about:

## Overview

Base input element to toggle an option on and off.

## API Reference

This component inherits props from the Checkbox primitive and supports common margin props.

## Overview

This section provides links to getting started, styling, layout, releases, and resources.

## Theme

This section covers theme-related topics such as overview, color, dark mode, typography, spacing, breakpoints, radius, and shadows.

## Layout

This section includes layout components like Box, Flex, Grid, Container, and Section.

## Typography

This section covers typography components such as Text, Heading, Blockquote, Code, Em, Kbd, Link, Quote, and Strong.

## Components

This section lists various components available in Radix UI, including Alert Dialog, Avatar, Button, Card, Checkbox, Dialog, Dropdown Menu, and more.

## Utilities

This section includes utility components like Accessible Icon, Portal, Reset, Slot, Theme, and Visually Hidden.

## Components - Card

Container that groups related content and actions. This section includes a detailed description of the Card component, its usage, and examples.

This should give you a solid starting point!

User: Can you explain what Avatar Component Documentation is in radix-ui-themes?

Assistant: Sure, I'd be happy to explain Avatar Component Documentation in radix-ui-themes.

# Avatar Component Documentation

Documentation for the Avatar component in Radix UI, including usage, API reference, examples, and props.Here's a quick rundown of what this is about:

## Overview

The Avatar component is used to display a profile picture, user initials, or a fallback icon.

## API Reference

This component inherits props from the Avatar primitive. The available props include: 
- `asChild`: boolean, no default value
- `size`: Responsive enum, default is '3'
- `variant`: 'solid' | 'soft', default is 'soft'
- `color`: enum, no default value
- `highContrast`: boolean, no default value
- `radius`: 'none' | 'small' | 'medium' | 'large' | 'full', no default value
- `fallback`: ReactNode, no default value.

## Examples

Various examples demonstrating the usage of the Avatar component, including size, variant, color, high-contrast, radius, and fallback.

This should give you a solid starting point!

## Overview

This section provides an overview of the Radix UI themes, including links to getting started, styling, layout, releases, and resources.

Details about theme customization, including color, dark mode, typography, spacing, breakpoints, radius, and shadows.

## Layout

Information on layout components such as Box, Flex, Grid, Container, and Section.

## Typography

Guidelines for typography components including Text, Heading, Blockquote, Code, Em, Kbd, Link, Quote, and Strong.

## Components

A list of available components in Radix UI themes, including Alert Dialog, Avatar, Button, Card, Checkbox, Dialog, Dropdown Menu, and more.

## Utilities

Utilities provided by Radix UI themes, including Accessible Icon, Portal, Reset, Slot, Theme, and Visually Hidden.

## Spinner

Displays an animated loading indicator. This section includes API reference, examples, and usage guidelines.

This should give you a solid starting point!

# Select Component Documentation

Documentation for the Select component in Radix UI, detailing usage, API reference, examples, and best practices.Here's a quick rundown of what this is about:

## Overview

The Select component displays a list of options for the user to pick from, triggered by a button.

## API Reference

System: You are a helpful radix-ui-themes expert.

User: Can you give me some code examples for Select Component Documentation in radix-ui-themes?

Assistant: Absolutely! Here are some practical examples to help you out:

**Basic Select Example**:

```yaml
<Select.Root defaultValue="apple">
	<Select.Trigger />
	<Select.Content>
		<Select.Group>
			<Select.Label>Fruits</Select.Label>
			<Select.Item value="orange">Orange</Select.Item>
			<Select.Item value="apple">Apple</Select.Item>
			<Select.Item value="grape" disabled>
				Grape
			</Select.Item>
		</Select.Group>
		<Select.Separator />
		<Select.Group>
			<Select.Label>Vegetables</Select.Label>
			<Select.Item value="carrot">Carrot</Select.Item>
			<Select.Item value="potato">Potato</Select.Item>
		</Select.Group>
	</Select.Content>
</Select.Root>
```

# Radix UI Themes Documentation

Comprehensive documentation for Radix UI themes, including components, layout, typography, and utilities.Here's a quick rundown of what this is about:

## Overview

This section provides links to getting started, styling, layout, releases, and resources.

## Theme

This section covers theme-related topics such as overview, color, dark mode, typography, spacing, breakpoints, radius, and shadows.

## Layout

This section includes layout components like Box, Flex, Grid, Container, and Section.

## Typography

This section covers typography components such as Text, Heading, Blockquote, Code, Em, Kbd, Link, Quote, and Strong.

## Components

This section lists various components available in Radix UI, including Alert Dialog, Aspect Ratio, Avatar, Badge, Button, Callout, Card, Checkbox, and many more.

## Utilities

This section includes utility components like Accessible Icon, Portal, Reset, Slot, Theme, and Visually Hidden.

## Components - Switch

Toggle switch alternative to the checkbox. Includes links to view source, report an issue, and view in playground.

## API Reference

This section provides details about the props available for the Switch component, including size, variant, color, highContrast, and radius.

## Examples

This section provides various examples of how to use the Switch component with different props such as size, variant, color, high-contrast, radius, alignment, and disabled.

This should give you a solid starting point!

```yaml

```

**Size Example**:

```yaml

	<Switch size="1" defaultChecked />
	<Switch size="2" defaultChecked />

</Flex>
```

**Variant Example**:

```yaml

		<Switch variant="classic" />

	<Flex direction="column" gap="3">
		<Switch variant="surface" defaultChecked />
		<Switch variant="classic" defaultChecked />

**Radius Example**:

```yaml
<Flex gap="3">
	<Switch radius="none" defaultChecked />
	<Switch radius="small" defaultChecked />
	<Switch radius="full" defaultChecked />
</Flex>
```

This snippet shows you how to radius example, which is an important aspect of radix ui themes documentation.

**Alignment Example**:

	</Text>
</Flex>
```

Use the `color` prop to assign a specific color.

System: You are a helpful radix-ui-themes expert.

User: What are some tips for using Progress Component Documentation in radix-ui-themes effectively?

Assistant: Great question! Here are some tips to keep in mind:

Use the `size` prop to control the size of the progress bar.

Use the `variant` prop to control the visual style of the progress bar.

Use the `color` prop to assign a specific color to the progress bar.

Use the `highContrast` prop to increase color contrast with the background.

Use the `radius` prop to assign a specific radius value to the progress bar.

Use the `value` prop to provide a precise indication of the task progress.

Use the `duration` prop to indicate an approximate duration of an indeterminate task.

Stick to these, and you'll avoid a lot of headaches!

Assistant: Sure, I'd be happy to explain Dialog in radix-ui-themes.

# Dialog

Modal dialog window displayed above the page.Here's a quick rundown of what this is about:

## Overview

This section provides an overview of the Dialog component, including its purpose and usage.

## API Reference

This component inherits props from the Dialog primitive. Note that this dialog is designed around the modal pattern, so the modal prop is unavailable.

## Examples

This section includes various examples demonstrating how to use the Dialog component, including size variations and inset content.

## Size

Use the size prop to control the size of the dialog. It will affect the padding and border-radius of the Content.

## With inset content

Use the Inset component to align content flush with the sides of the dialog.

This should give you a solid starting point!

# Radix UI Themes Documentation

Comprehensive documentation for Radix UI themes, including components, utilities, and best practices.Here's a quick rundown of what this is about:

## Overview

This section provides an introduction to the Radix UI themes, including links to getting started, styling, layout, releases, and resources.

## Theme

Details about theme customization, including color, dark mode, typography, spacing, breakpoints, radius, and shadows.

## Layout

Information on layout components such as Box, Flex, Grid, Container, and Section.

## Typography

Guidelines and components related to typography, including Text, Heading, Blockquote, Code, Em, Kbd, Link, Quote, and Strong.

## Components

A comprehensive list of UI components available in Radix UI, including Alert Dialog, Avatar, Button, Card, Checkbox, Dialog, Dropdown Menu, and more.

## Utilities

Utilities provided by Radix UI, including Accessible Icon, Portal, Reset, Slot, Theme, and Visually Hidden.

## Components - Strong

Details about the Strong component, which marks text to signify strong importance.

This should give you a solid starting point!

System: You are a helpful radix-ui-themes expert.

User: Can you explain what Radius is in radix-ui-themes?

Assistant: Sure, I'd be happy to explain Radius in radix-ui-themes.

# Radius

Choosing the right radius setting in your theme.Here's a quick rundown of what this is about:

## Theme setting

Theme `radius` setting manages the radius factor applied to the components:

```jsx
<Theme radius="medium">
	<TextField.Root size="3" placeholder="Reply…">
		<TextField.Slot side="right" px="1">
			<Button size="2">Send</Button>
		</TextField.Slot>
	</TextField.Root>
</Theme>
```

`none`

Send

`small`

Send

`medium`

Send

`large`

Send

`full`

Send

The resulting `border-radius` is contextual and differs depending on the component. For example, when set to `full`, a [Button](https://www.radix-ui.com/themes/docs/components/button) becomes pill-shaped, while a [Checkbox](https://www.radix-ui.com/themes/docs/components/checkbox) will never become fully rounded to prevent any confusion between it and a [Radio](https://www.radix-ui.com/themes/docs/components/radio).

## Radius overrides

Certain components allow you to override the radius factor using their own `radius` prop.

SaveSaveSaveSaveSave

```jsx
<Flex align="center" gap="3">
	<Button radius="none">Save</Button>
	<Button radius="small">Save</Button>
	<Button radius="medium">Save</Button>
	<Button radius="large">Save</Button>
	<Button radius="full">Save</Button>
</Flex>
```

Components that render panels, like Card, Dialog, and Popover, among others, won’t have the `radius` prop, but will inherit the radius setting from the theme. The `radius` prop is also unavailable on most text-based components.

## Radius scale

Radius values used in the components are derived from a 6-step scale.

1

2

3

4

5

6

While you can’t use a specific step on a particular component directly—the `radius` prop is used to set just the radius factor—you can use the radius scale to style your own components.

Radius tokens are accessed using CSS variables. You can use these tokens to style your custom components, ensuring they are consistent with the rest of your theme.

```css
/* Radius values that automatically respond to the radius factor */
var(--radius-1);
var(--radius-2);
var(--radius-3);
var(--radius-4);
var(--radius-5);
var(--radius-6);

/* A multiplier that controls the theme radius */
var(--radius-factor);

/*
 * A variable used to calculate a fully rounded radius.
 * Usually used within a CSS `max()` function.
 */
var(--radius-full);

/*
 * A variable used to calculate radius of a thumb element.
 * Usually used within a CSS `max()` function.
 */
var(--radius-thumb);
```

This should give you a solid starting point!

**Radius scale CSS example**:

```yaml
/* Radius values that automatically respond to the radius factor */
var(--radius-1);

/*
 * A variable used to calculate radius of a thumb element.

 */

```

User: What are some tips for using Radius in radix-ui-themes effectively?

Assistant: Great question! Here are some tips to keep in mind:

The resulting `border-radius` is contextual and differs depending on the component.

Components that render panels, like Card, Dialog, and Popover, among others, won’t have the `radius` prop, but will inherit the radius setting from the theme.

Stick to these, and you'll avoid a lot of headaches!

# Radix UI Themes Documentation

Comprehensive documentation for Radix UI themes, including components, layout, typography, and utilities.Here's a quick rundown of what this is about:

## Overview

This section provides an overview of the Radix UI themes, including links to getting started, styling, layout, releases, and resources.

## Theme

Details about theme customization, including color, dark mode, typography, spacing, breakpoints, radius, and shadows.

## Layout

Information on layout components such as Box, Flex, Grid, Container, and Section.

## Typography

Guidelines for typography components including Text, Heading, Blockquote, Code, Em, Kbd, Link, Quote, and Strong.

## Components

A list of available components in Radix UI themes, including Alert Dialog, Avatar, Button, Card, Checkbox, Dialog, Dropdown Menu, and more.

## Utilities

Utilities provided by Radix UI themes, including Accessible Icon, Portal, Reset, Slot, Theme, and Visually Hidden.

## Callout

Short message to attract user’s attention. Includes examples and API reference for the Callout component.

This should give you a solid starting point!

User: Can you give me some code examples for Radix Themes Documentation in radix-ui-themes?

Assistant: Absolutely! Here are some practical examples to help you out:

**Setting Accent Color**:

```yaml
<Theme accentColor="indigo">
	<MyApp />
</Theme>
```

This snippet shows you how to setting accent color, which is an important aspect of radix themes documentation.

**Using Gray Color**:

```yaml
<Theme grayColor="mauve">
	<MyApp />
</Theme>
```

This snippet shows you how to using gray color, which is an important aspect of radix themes documentation.

**Accessing Accent Scale Tokens**:

```yaml
var(--accent-1);
var(--accent-2);
var(--accent-3);
var(--accent-4);
var(--accent-5);
var(--accent-6);
var(--accent-7);
var(--accent-8);
var(--accent-9);
var(--accent-10);
var(--accent-11);
var(--accent-12);
```

This snippet shows you how to accessing accent scale tokens, which is an important aspect of radix themes documentation.

**Using Color Overrides**:

```yaml
<Theme accentColor="indigo">
	<Flex align="start" direction={{ initial: "column", sm: "row" }} gap="4">
		<Callout.Root>
			<Callout.Icon>
				<InfoCircledIcon />
			</Callout.Icon>
			<Callout.Text>
				<Flex as="span" align="center" gap="4">
					<Text>There are new commits.</Text>
					<Button variant="surface" size="1" my="-2">
						Refresh
					</Button>
				</Flex>
			</Callout.Text>
		</Callout.Root>
		<Callout.Root color="gray">
			<Callout.Icon>
				<InfoCircledIcon />
			</Callout.Icon>
			<Callout.Text>
				<Flex as="span" align="center" gap="4">
					<Text>There are new commits.</Text>
					<Button variant="surface" size="1" my="-2">
						Refresh
					</Button>
				</Flex>
			</Callout.Text>
		</Callout.Root>
	</Flex>
</Theme>
```

This snippet shows you how to using color overrides, which is an important aspect of radix themes documentation.

**Using Individual CSS Files**:

```yaml
import "@radix-ui/themes/tokens/base.css";
import "@radix-ui/themes/tokens/colors/ruby.css";
import "@radix-ui/themes/tokens/colors/teal.css";
import "@radix-ui/themes/tokens/colors/slate.css";
import "@radix-ui/themes/components.css";
import "@radix-ui/themes/utilities.css";
```

This snippet shows you how to using individual css files, which is an important aspect of radix themes documentation.

text:
System: You are a helpful radix-ui-themes expert.

User: Can you explain what Layout Overview is in radix-ui-themes?

Assistant: Sure, I'd be happy to explain Layout Overview in radix-ui-themes.

# Layout Overview

Get the layout concerns right.Here's a quick rundown of what this is about:

## Layout components

Layout components are used to separate layout responsibilities from content and interactivity. This is _the_ separation of concerns that makes your app maintainable and easy to reason about, and understanding these principles is key to building your interfaces effectively.

## Box

[Box](https://www.radix-ui.com/themes/docs/components/box) is the most fundamental layout component. Box is used to:

- Provide spacing to child elements.
- Impose sizing constraints on content.
- Control layout behaviour within flex and grid containers.
- Hide content based on screen size using its responsive `display` prop.

## Flex

[Flex](https://www.radix-ui.com/themes/docs/components/flex) component does everything that Box can do, but comes with an additional set of props to organize items along an axis. It provides convenient access to the CSS [flexbox properties](https://css-tricks.com/snippets/css/a-guide-to-flexbox/)

## Grid

[Grid](https://www.radix-ui.com/themes/docs/components/grid) is used to organize the content in columns and rows. Like Box and Flex, it’s made to provide convenient access to the underlying CSS [grid properties](https://css-tricks.com/snippets/css/complete-guide-grid/) without any magic of its own.

## Section

[Section](https://www.radix-ui.com/themes/docs/components/section) provides a consistent vertical spacing between the larger parts of your page content, creating a sense of hierarchy and separation. There’s just a few pre-defined sizes for different spacing levels to keep things simple and consistent.

## Container

[Container](https://www.radix-ui.com/themes/docs/components/container)’s sole responsibility is to provide a consistent `max-width` to the content it wraps. Like Section, it comes just with a couple of pre-defined sizes that work well with common breakpoints and typical content widths for comfortable reading.

## Common layout props

Each layout component has a set of it’s own specialized props and also a shared set of common layout props. All layout props support [responsive object values](https://www.radix-ui.com/themes/docs/theme/breakpoints).

## Padding

Padding props can access the [space scale steps](https://www.radix-ui.com/themes/docs/theme/spacing) or accept any valid [CSS padding value](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/padding).

## Width

Width props accept any valid [CSS width value](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/width).

## Height

Height props accept any valid [CSS height value](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/height).

## Positioning

Positioning props can change how the element is placed relative to the normal flow of the document. As usual, the corresponding CSS values are accepted for each property, and the [space scale steps](https://www.radix-ui.com/themes/docs/theme/spacing) can be used for the offset values.

## Flex children

Each layout component has props used to control the style when it is a child of a flex container.

## Grid children

Each layout component has props used to control the style when it is a child of a grid container.

## Margin props

Margin props are available on most components in order to provide spacing around the elements. They are not exclusive to layout components.

## Standalone usage

If needed, it’s possible to use _just_ the layout component from Radix Themes. Just make sure that JavaScript tree-shaking works on your side, and import the CSS that powers the layout styles.

This should give you a solid starting point!

# Radix UI Themes Documentation

Comprehensive documentation for Radix UI themes, including components, utilities, and styling guidelines.Here's a quick rundown of what this is about:

## Overview

This section provides an introduction to the Radix UI themes, including links to getting started, styling, layout, releases, and resources.

## Theme

Details about theme customization, including color, dark mode, typography, spacing, breakpoints, radius, and shadows.

## Layout

Information on layout components such as Box, Flex, Grid, Container, and Section.

## Typography

Guidelines for typography components including Text, Heading, Blockquote, Code, Em, Kbd, Link, Quote, and Strong.

## Components

A comprehensive list of UI components available in Radix UI themes, including Alert Dialog, Avatar, Button, Card, Checkbox, Dialog, Dropdown Menu, and more.

## Utilities

Overview of utility components like Accessible Icon, Portal, Reset, Slot, Theme, and Visually Hidden.

## Slot

Merges its props onto its immediate child. This component inherits all props and functionality from the Slot primitive utility.

## API Reference

Detailed API reference for the Slot component, including links to source code and issue reporting.

This should give you a solid starting point!

# Radio Cards

Set of interactive cards where only one can be selected at a time.Here's a quick rundown of what this is about:

## Overview

This section provides an overview of the Radio Cards component, including links to getting started, styling, layout, releases, and resources.

## API Reference

This section details the API reference for the Radio Cards component, including the props for the Root and Item components.

## Examples

This section provides various examples of how to use the Radio Cards component, including size, variant, color, high-contrast, and disabled states.

This should give you a solid starting point!

System: You are a helpful radix-ui-themes expert.

User: Can you give me some code examples for Radio Cards in radix-ui-themes?

Assistant: Absolutely! Here are some practical examples to help you out:

**Basic Radio Cards Example**:

```yaml
<Box maxWidth="600px">
	<RadioCards.Root defaultValue="1" columns={{ initial: "1", sm: "3" }}>
		<RadioCards.Item value="1">
			<Flex direction="column" width="100%">
				<Text weight="bold">8-core CPU</Text>
				<Text>32 GB RAM</Text>
			</Flex>
		</RadioCards.Item>
		<RadioCards.Item value="2">
			<Flex direction="column" width="100%">
				<Text weight="bold">6-core CPU</Text>
				<Text>24 GB RAM</Text>
			</Flex>
		</RadioCards.Item>
		<RadioCards.Item value="3">
			<Flex direction="column" width="100%">
				<Text weight="bold">4-core CPU</Text>
				<Text>16 GB RAM</Text>
			</Flex>
		</RadioCards.Item>
	</RadioCards.Root>
</Box>
```

This snippet shows you how to basic radio cards example, which is an important aspect of radio cards.

**Size Example**:

```yaml
<Flex align="center" gap="3">
	<RadioCards.Root size="1">
		<RadioCards.Item value="1">8-core CPU</RadioCards.Item>
	</RadioCards.Root>
	<RadioCards.Root size="2">
		<RadioCards.Item value="1">8-core CPU</RadioCards.Item>
	</RadioCards.Root>
	<RadioCards.Root size="3">
		<RadioCards.Item value="1">8-core CPU</RadioCards.Item>
	</RadioCards.Root>
</Flex>
```

This snippet shows you how to size example, which is an important aspect of radio cards.

**Variant Example**:

```yaml
<Flex direction="column" gap="3" maxWidth="200px">
	<RadioCards.Root variant="surface">
		<RadioCards.Item value="1">8-core CPU</RadioCards.Item>
	</RadioCards.Root>
	<RadioCards.Root variant="classic">
		<RadioCards.Item value="1">8-core CPU</RadioCards.Item>
	</RadioCards.Root>
</Flex>
```

This snippet shows you how to variant example, which is an important aspect of radio cards.

**Color Example**:

```yaml
<Flex direction="column" gap="3" maxWidth="200px">
	<RadioCards.Root defaultValue="1" color="indigo">
		<RadioCards.Item value="1">8-core CPU</RadioCards.Item>
	</RadioCards.Root>
	<RadioCards.Root defaultValue="1" color="cyan">
		<RadioCards.Item value="1">8-core CPU</RadioCards.Item>
	</RadioCards.Root>
	<RadioCards.Root defaultValue="1" color="orange">
		<RadioCards.Item value="1">8-core CPU</RadioCards.Item>
	</RadioCards.Root>
	<RadioCards.Root defaultValue="1" color="crimson">
		<RadioCards.Item value="1">8-core CPU</RadioCards.Item>
	</RadioCards.Root>
</Flex>
```

This snippet shows you how to color example, which is an important aspect of radio cards.

**High-contrast Example**:

```yaml
<Grid columns="2" gap="3" display="inline-grid">
	<RadioCards.Root defaultValue="1" color="indigo">
		<RadioCards.Item value="1">8-core CPU</RadioCards.Item>
	</RadioCards.Root>
	<RadioCards.Root defaultValue="1" color="indigo" highContrast>
		<RadioCards.Item value="1">8-core CPU</RadioCards.Item>
	</RadioCards.Root>
	<RadioCards.Root defaultValue="1" color="cyan">
		<RadioCards.Item value="1">8-core CPU</RadioCards.Item>
	</RadioCards.Root>
	<RadioCards.Root defaultValue="1" color="cyan" highContrast>
		<RadioCards.Item value="1">8-core CPU</RadioCards.Item>
	</RadioCards.Root>
	<RadioCards.Root defaultValue="1" color="orange">
		<RadioCards.Item value="1">8-core CPU</RadioCards.Item>
	</RadioCards.Root>
	<RadioCards.Root defaultValue="1" color="orange" highContrast>
		<RadioCards.Item value="1">8-core CPU</RadioCards.Item>
	</RadioCards.Root>
	<RadioCards.Root defaultValue="1" color="crimson">
		<RadioCards.Item value="1">8-core CPU</RadioCards.Item>
	</RadioCards.Root>
	<RadioCards.Root defaultValue="1" color="crimson" highContrast>
		<RadioCards.Item value="1">8-core CPU</RadioCards.Item>
	</RadioCards.Root>
</Grid>
```

This snippet shows you how to high-contrast example, which is an important aspect of radio cards.

**Disabled Example**:

```yaml
<Flex direction="column" gap="4" maxWidth="450px">
	<RadioCards.Root columns="2" defaultValue="2">
		<RadioCards.Item value="1">Off</RadioCards.Item>
		<RadioCards.Item value="2">On</RadioCards.Item>
	</RadioCards.Root>
	<RadioCards.Root columns="2" defaultValue="2">

			Off
		</RadioCards.Item>

			On
		</RadioCards.Item>

System: You are a helpful radix-ui-themes expert.

User: What are some tips for using Radio Cards in radix-ui-themes effectively?

Assistant: Great question! Here are some tips to keep in mind:

Use the `size` prop to control the size of the Radio Cards.

Use the `variant` prop to control the visual style of the Radio Cards.

Use the `color` prop to assign a specific color to the Radio Cards.

Use the `highContrast` prop to increase color contrast with the background.

Stick to these, and you'll avoid a lot of headaches!

# Radix UI Themes Documentation

Comprehensive documentation for Radix UI themes, including components, layout, typography, and utilities.Here's a quick rundown of what this is about:

## Overview

This section provides links to getting started, styling, layout, releases, and resources.

## Theme

This section covers theme-related topics such as overview, color, dark mode, typography, spacing, breakpoints, radius, and shadows.

Prop description | `boolean` | No default value | | `size` | `Responsive<"1" | "2" | "3">` | "2" | | `variant`
Prop description | "surface" | "classic" | "surface" | | `color`
Prop description | `enum`
See full type | No default value | | `highContrast`
Prop description | `boolean` | No default value | | `columns` | `Responsive`
See full type | "repeat(auto-fit, minmax(200px, 1fr))" | | `gap` | `Responsive`
See full type | "4" | ## Item An item in the group that can be checked. ## Examples This section provides various examples of how to use the Checkbox Cards component. ## Size Use the `size` prop to control the size. ## Variant Use the `variant` prop to control the visual style. ## Color Use the `color` prop to assign a specific color. ## High-contrast Use the `highContrast` prop to increase color contrast with the background. ## Disabled This section describes how to use the disabled state for Checkbox Cards. This should give you a solid starting point!

# Radio Group

Set of interactive radio buttons where only one can be selected at a time.Here's a quick rundown of what this is about:

## Overview

This section provides an overview of the Radio Group component, including links to getting started, styling, layout, releases, and resources.

## API Reference

text:
System: You are a helpful radix-ui-themes expert.

User: How do I examples in radix-ui-themes?

Assistant: To examples in radix-ui-themes, here's what you do:
### Size
Use the `size` prop to control the size.

```jsx
<Flex direction="column" gap="3">
	<Box maxWidth="200px">
		<TextArea size="1" placeholder="Reply to comment…" />
	</Box>
	<Box maxWidth="250px">
		<TextArea size="2" placeholder="Reply to comment…" />
	</Box>
	<Box maxWidth="300px">
		<TextArea size="3" placeholder="Reply to comment…" />
	</Box>
</Flex>
```

### Variant
Use the `variant` prop to control the visual style.

```jsx
<Flex direction="column" gap="3" maxWidth="250px">
	<TextArea variant="surface" placeholder="Reply to comment…" />
	<TextArea variant="classic" placeholder="Reply to comment…" />
	<TextArea variant="soft" placeholder="Reply to comment…" />
</Flex>
```

### Color
Use the `color` prop to assign a specific [color](https://www.radix-ui.com/themes/docs/theme/color).

```jsx
<Flex direction="column" gap="3" maxWidth="250px">
	<TextArea color="blue" variant="soft" placeholder="Reply to comment…" />
	<TextArea color="green" variant="soft" placeholder="Reply to comment…" />
	<TextArea color="red" variant="soft" placeholder="Reply to comment…" />
</Flex>
```

### Radius
Use the `radius` prop to assign a specific radius value.

```jsx
<Flex direction="column" gap="3" maxWidth="250px">
	<TextArea radius="none" placeholder="Search the docs…" />
	<TextArea radius="large" placeholder="Search the docs…" />
	<TextArea radius="full" placeholder="Search the docs…" />
</Flex>
```

### Resize
Use the `resize` prop to enable resizing on one or both axis.

```jsx
<Flex direction="column" gap="3" maxWidth="250px">
	<TextArea resize="none" placeholder="Search the docs…" />
	<TextArea resize="vertical" placeholder="Search the docs…" />
	<TextArea resize="horizontal" placeholder="Search the docs…" />
	<TextArea resize="both" placeholder="Search the docs…" />
</Flex>
```.
Pretty straightforward, right?

# Segmented Control

Toggle buttons for switching between different values or views.Here's a quick rundown of what this is about:

## Overview

This component allows users to switch between different values or views using toggle buttons.

## API Reference

This component inherits props and functionality from the Toggle Group primitive. It supports common margin props.

## Root

Contains the items of the control.

## Item

Represents individual values of the control.

## Examples

Examples demonstrating the usage of the Segmented Control component.

## Size

Use the size prop to control the size of the control.

## Variant

Use the variant prop to control the visual style of the control.

## Radius

Use the radius prop to assign a specific radius value.

This should give you a solid starting point!

System: You are a helpful radix-ui-themes expert. User: Can you explain what Icon Button is in radix-ui-themes? Assistant: Sure, I'd be happy to explain Icon Button in radix-ui-themes. # Icon Button Button designed specifically for usage with a single icon.Here's a quick rundown of what this is about: ## Overview This component is based on the `button` element and supports [common margin props](https://www.radix-ui.com/themes/docs/overview/layout#margin-props). ## API Reference | Prop | Type | Default | | --- | --- | --- | | `asChild`
Prop description | `boolean` | No default value | | `size` | `Responsive<"1" | "2" | "3" | "4">` | "2" | | `variant`
Prop description | `enum`
See full type | "solid" | | `color`
Prop description | `enum`
See full type | No default value | | `highContrast`
Prop description | `boolean` | No default value | | `radius`
Prop description | "none" | "small" | "medium" | "large" | "full" | No default value | | `loading` | `boolean` | `false` | ## Examples ### Size Use the `size` prop to control the size of the button. ```jsx ``` ### Variant Use the `variant` prop to control the visual style of the button. ```jsx ``` #### Ghost Use the `ghost` variant to display a button without chrome. Ghost buttons behave like text in layout, as they use a negative margin to optically align themselves against their siblings while maintaining the padding in active and hover states. ```jsx ``` ### Color Use the `color` prop to assign a specific [color](https://www.radix-ui.com/themes/docs/theme/color). ```jsx ``` ### High-contrast Use the `highContrast` prop to increase color contrast with the background. ```jsx ``` ### Radius Use the `radius` prop to assign a specific radius value. ```jsx ``` ### Loading Use the `loading` prop to display a loading spinner in place of button content. The button will be disabled while loading. ```jsx ``` This should give you a solid starting point!

text:
System: You are a helpful radix-ui-themes expert.

User: How do I examples in radix-ui-themes?

Assistant: To examples in radix-ui-themes, here's what you do:
### Size
Use the `size` prop to control the size of the button.

```jsx
<Flex align="center" gap="3">
	<IconButton size="1" variant="soft">
		<MagnifyingGlassIcon width="15" height="15" />
	</IconButton>
	<IconButton size="2" variant="soft">
		<MagnifyingGlassIcon width="18" height="18" />
	</IconButton>
	<IconButton size="3" variant="soft">
		<MagnifyingGlassIcon width="22" height="22" />
	</IconButton>
</Flex>
```

### Variant
Use the `variant` prop to control the visual style of the button.

```jsx
<Flex gap="3">
	<IconButton variant="classic">
		<MagnifyingGlassIcon width="18" height="18" />
	</IconButton>
	<IconButton variant="solid">
		<MagnifyingGlassIcon width="18" height="18" />
	</IconButton>
	<IconButton variant="soft">
		<MagnifyingGlassIcon width="18" height="18" />
	</IconButton>
	<IconButton variant="surface">
		<MagnifyingGlassIcon width="18" height="18" />
	</IconButton>
	<IconButton variant="outline">
		<MagnifyingGlassIcon width="18" height="18" />
	</IconButton>
</Flex>
```

#### Ghost
Use the `ghost` variant to display a button without chrome. Ghost buttons behave like text in layout, as they use a negative margin to optically align themselves against their siblings while maintaining the padding in active and hover states.

```jsx
<IconButton variant="ghost">
	<MagnifyingGlassIcon width="18" height="18" />
</IconButton>
```

### Color
Use the `color` prop to assign a specific [color](https://www.radix-ui.com/themes/docs/theme/color).

```jsx
<Flex gap="3">
	<IconButton color="crimson" variant="soft">
		<MagnifyingGlassIcon width="18" height="18" />
	</IconButton>
	<IconButton color="indigo" variant="soft">
		<MagnifyingGlassIcon width="18" height="18" />
	</IconButton>
	<IconButton color="grass" variant="soft">
		<MagnifyingGlassIcon width="18" height="18" />
	</IconButton>
	<IconButton color="orange" variant="soft">
		<MagnifyingGlassIcon width="18" height="18" />
	</IconButton>
</Flex>
```

### High-contrast
Use the `highContrast` prop to increase color contrast with the background.

```jsx
<Flex direction="column" gap="3">
	<Flex gap="3">
		<IconButton color="gray" variant="classic">
			<MagnifyingGlassIcon width="18" height="18" />
		</IconButton>
		<IconButton color="gray" variant="solid">
			<MagnifyingGlassIcon width="18" height="18" />
		</IconButton>
		<IconButton color="gray" variant="soft">
			<MagnifyingGlassIcon width="18" height="18" />
		</IconButton>
		<IconButton color="gray" variant="surface">
			<MagnifyingGlassIcon width="18" height="18" />
		</IconButton>
		<IconButton color="gray" variant="outline">
			<MagnifyingGlassIcon width="18" height="18" />
		</IconButton>
	</Flex>
	<Flex gap="3">
		<IconButton color="gray" variant="classic" highContrast>
			<MagnifyingGlassIcon width="18" height="18" />
		</IconButton>
		<IconButton color="gray" variant="solid" highContrast>
			<MagnifyingGlassIcon width="18" height="18" />
		</IconButton>
		<IconButton color="gray" variant="soft" highContrast>
			<MagnifyingGlassIcon width="18" height="18" />
		</IconButton>
		<IconButton color="gray" variant="surface" highContrast>
			<MagnifyingGlassIcon width="18" height="18" />
		</IconButton>
		<IconButton color="gray" variant="outline" highContrast>
			<MagnifyingGlassIcon width="18" height="18" />
		</IconButton>
	</Flex>
</Flex>
```

### Radius
Use the `radius` prop to assign a specific radius value.

```jsx
<Flex gap="3">
	<IconButton radius="none" variant="soft">
		<MagnifyingGlassIcon width="18" height="18" />
	</IconButton>
	<IconButton radius="large" variant="soft">
		<MagnifyingGlassIcon width="18" height="18" />
	</IconButton>
	<IconButton radius="full" variant="soft">
		<MagnifyingGlassIcon width="18" height="18" />
	</IconButton>
</Flex>
```

### Loading
Use the `loading` prop to display a loading spinner in place of button content. The button will be disabled while loading.

```jsx
<Flex gap="3">
	<IconButton loading variant="classic">
		<MagnifyingGlassIcon width="18" height="18" />
	</IconButton>
	<IconButton loading variant="solid">
		<MagnifyingGlassIcon width="18" height="18" />
	</IconButton>
	<IconButton loading variant="soft">
		<MagnifyingGlassIcon width="18" height="18" />
	</IconButton>
	<IconButton loading variant="surface">
		<MagnifyingGlassIcon width="18" height="18" />
	</IconButton>
	<IconButton loading variant="outline">
		<MagnifyingGlassIcon width="18" height="18" />
	</IconButton>
</Flex>
```.
Pretty straightforward, right?

System: You are a helpful radix-ui-themes expert.

User: Can you explain what Radix UI Themes Documentation is in radix-ui-themes?

Assistant: Sure, I'd be happy to explain Radix UI Themes Documentation in radix-ui-themes.

# Radix UI Themes Documentation

Comprehensive guide on Radix UI themes, including components, layout, typography, and dark mode integration.Here's a quick rundown of what this is about:

## Overview

This section provides an introduction to the Radix UI themes, including links to getting started, styling, layout, releases, and resources.

## Theme

Details about theme customization, including color, dark mode, typography, spacing, breakpoints, radius, shadows, and cursors.

## Layout

Information on layout components such as Box, Flex, Grid, Container, and Section.

## Typography

Guidelines for typography components including Text, Heading, Blockquote, Code, Em, Kbd, Link, Quote, and Strong.

## Components

A list of various UI components available in Radix UI, including Alert Dialog, Avatar, Button, Card, Checkbox, Dialog, Dropdown Menu, and more.

## Utilities

Overview of utility components like Accessible Icon, Portal, Reset, Slot, Theme, and Visually Hidden.

## Guides

This section includes guides on specific topics, such as dark mode.

## Dark mode

Using appearance to manage and integrate dark mode.

System: You are a helpful radix-ui-themes expert.

User: Can you give me some code examples for Radix UI Themes Documentation in radix-ui-themes?

Assistant: Absolutely! Here are some practical examples to help you out:

**Basic usage of Theme**:

```yaml
<Theme appearance="dark">
	<MyApp />
</Theme>
```

This snippet shows you how to basic usage of theme, which is an important aspect of radix ui themes documentation.

**Inheriting system appearance with next-themes**:

```yaml
import { Theme } from "@radix-ui/themes";
import { ThemeProvider } from "next-themes";

export default function () {
	return (
		<ThemeProvider attribute="class">
			<Theme>
				<MyApp />
			</Theme>
		</ThemeProvider>
	);
}
```

This snippet shows you how to inheriting system appearance with next-themes, which is an important aspect of radix ui themes documentation.

System: You are a helpful radix-ui-themes expert.

User: What are some tips for using Radix UI Themes Documentation in radix-ui-themes effectively?

Assistant: Great question! Here are some tips to keep in mind:

Do not try to set <Theme appearance={resolvedTheme}>. Instead, rely just on class switching that next-themes provides to prevent appearance flash during initial render.

Ensure that the appended class names match those supported by Radix Themes: className="light", className="light-theme", className="dark", className="dark-theme".

Stick to these, and you'll avoid a lot of headaches!

User: Can you explain what Scroll Area is in radix-ui-themes?

Assistant: Sure, I'd be happy to explain Scroll Area in radix-ui-themes.

# Scroll Area

Custom-styled scrollable area using native functionality.Here's a quick rundown of what this is about:

## Overview

This section provides an overview of the Scroll Area component, including its purpose and functionality.

## Principles of the typographic craft

Three fundamental aspects of typography are legibility, readability, and aesthetics. Although in a non-technical sense 'legible' and 'readable' are often used synonymously, typographically they are separate but related concepts. Legibility describes how easily individual characters can be distinguished from one another. It is described by Walter Tracy as 'the quality of being decipherable and recognisable'. For instance, if a 'b' and an 'h', or a '3' and an '8', are difficult to distinguish at small sizes, this is a problem of legibility. Typographers are concerned with legibility insofar as it is their job to select the correct font to use. Brush Script is an example of a font containing many characters that might be difficult to distinguish. The selection of cases influences the legibility of typography because using only uppercase letters (all-caps) reduces legibility.

## API Reference

This component inherits props from the ScrollArea primitive Root and Viewport parts. It supports common margin props.

## Examples

This section provides various examples of how to use the Scroll Area component, including size, radius, and scrollbars.

This should give you a solid starting point!

User: Can you explain what Getting Started with Radix Themes is in radix-ui-themes?

Assistant: Sure, I'd be happy to explain Getting Started with Radix Themes in radix-ui-themes.

# Getting Started with Radix Themes

Install Radix Themes and start building in minutes with a pre-styled component library that works out of the box.Here's a quick rundown of what this is about:

## Overview

Radix Themes is a pre-styled component library that is designed to work out of the box with minimal configuration. If you are looking for the unstyled components, go to Radix Primitives.

## Installation

Getting up and running is quick and easy.

## 1. Install Radix Themes

Install the package from your command line.

## 2. Import the CSS file

Import the global CSS file at the root of your application.

## 3. Add the Theme component

Add `Theme` to your application, wrapping the root component inside of `body`.

## 4. Start building

You are now ready to use Radix Themes components.

## Customizing your theme

Configuration is managed and applied via the Theme component.

## Basic configuration

Pass configuration to the Theme to customize appearance.

## Using the theme panel

ThemePanel is a drop-in component that allows you to preview the theme in real time.

## Take it further

Get the most out of Radix Themes by exploring more concepts and features.

This should give you a solid starting point!

User: Can you give me some code examples for Hover Card in radix-ui-themes?

Assistant: Absolutely! Here are some practical examples to help you out:

**Basic Hover Card Example**:

```yaml
<Text>

	Follow{" "}

	<HoverCard.Root>

		<HoverCard.Trigger>

			<Link href="#" href="https://twitter.com/radix_ui" target="_blank">

				@radix_ui

			</Link>

		</HoverCard.Trigger>

		<HoverCard.Content maxWidth="300px">

			<Flex gap="4">

				<Avatar
					size="3"
					fallback="R"
					radius="full"
					src="https://pbs.twimg.com/profile_images/1337055608613253126/r_eiMp2H_400x400.png"
				/>

				<Box>

					<Heading size="3" as="h3">

						Radix

					</Heading>

					<Text as="div" size="2" color="gray" mb="2">

						@radix_ui

					</Text>

					<Text as="div" size="2">

						React components, icons, and colors for building high-quality,

						accessible UI.

					</Text>

				</Box>

			</Flex>

		</HoverCard.Content>

	</HoverCard.Root>{" "}

	for updates.

</Text>

```

This component is based on the `div` element and supports [common margin props](https://www.radix-ui.com/themes/docs/overview/layout#margin-props). | Prop | Type | Default | | --- | --- | --- | | `size` | `Responsive<"1" | "2" | "3">` | `"2"` | | `variant`
Prop description | `"classic" | "surface" | "soft"` | `"surface"` | | `color`
Prop description | `enum`
See full type | No default value | | `radius`
Prop description | `"none" | "small" | "medium" | "large" | "full"` | No default value | ### [Slot](https://www.radix-ui.com/themes/docs/components/text-field#slot) Contains icons or buttons associated with an Input. | Prop | Type | Default | | --- | --- | --- | | `side` | `"left" | "right"` | No default value | | `color`
Prop description | `enum`
See full type | No default value | | `gap` | `Responsive`
See full type | No default value | | `px` | `Responsive`
See full type | No default value | | `pl` | `Responsive`
See full type | No default value | | `pr` | `Responsive`
See full type | No default value | ## Examples ### [Size](https://www.radix-ui.com/themes/docs/components/text-field#size) Use the `size` prop to control the size. ```jsx ``` Use matching component sizes when composing Text Field with buttons. However, don’t use size 1 inputs with buttons—at this size, there is not enough vertical space to nest other interactive elements. ```jsx ``` ### [Variant](https://www.radix-ui.com/themes/docs/components/text-field#variant) Use the `variant` prop to control the visual style. ```jsx ``` ### [Color](https://www.radix-ui.com/themes/docs/components/text-field#color) Use the `color` prop to assign a specific [color](https://www.radix-ui.com/themes/docs/theme/color). ```jsx ``` ### [Radius](https://www.radix-ui.com/themes/docs/components/text-field#radius) Use the `radius` prop to assign a specific radius value. ```jsx ``` This should give you a solid starting point!
